Description: A rectangular ivory plaque, virtually complete. The left left hand corner is missing together with fragments from the surface. Carved in relief with a winged human-headed sphinx advancing left with a flowering "lily"-tendril in the background. The sphinx wears the crown of Upper and Lower Egypt, an Osiride beard and a pharaonic headcloth. About its neck is an usekh-collar and between its forelegs hangs an apron decorated with vertical bands of chevrons. Fragments of a tenon are preserved on the lower egde.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Professor Sir Max Edgar Lucien Mallowan
Bibliographic references: Barnett & Davies 1975a / A catalogue of Nimrud ivories with other examples of Ancient Near Eastern Ivories (pl.CXXXIV, Suppl.23)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2012 Jan-Apr, Hong Kong Museum of Art, Fantastic Creatures 2011 Jun-Sept, South Korea, Ulsan Museum, Fantastic Creatures 1988 Feb-Nov, Italy, Venice, Palazzo Grassi, I Fenici 1958 BM, G58/Nimrud Ivories
Acquisition name: Purchased from: British School of Archaeology, Iraq
Division of Finds: Department of Antiquities of Iraq
